> 40yahoogroups.com>,
>
> > > "ourobouros2k2" <ourobouros2k2@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > EVP itself defies categorization. Some folks think it is a modulated
> em
> > > field in proximity to the microphone. There is evidence to support
> this, as
> > > evp has been recorded in faraday cages and vacuum jars. It would then
> be
> > > logical to assume that evp is independent of vibratory sound waves.
> Then
> > > that is blown to hell when you consider that Waldemar Bogoras is
> credited
> > > with the first reported evp capture while recording rituals of the
> Tchoutki
> > > tribe in Siberia in 1901. The was with a mechanical gramaphone-like
> device,
> > > no microphone, just a horn to amplify sound, mechanical "write" needle,
> and
> > > wax cylinder. Electric gramaphones didn't come about till almost the
> '20s.
> > > In that case it would appear that evp exists as soundwaves and not em
> > > fields.
> > > >
> > > > Which one is right? Both probably, and that isn't even taking into
> > > account the mechanism involved in box-related evp.
> > > >
> > > > Intent and desire to communicate. The rest works itself out.
> > > >
> > > > Thanks
> > > > Andy
> > > >
> > >
> > > And all of this supports the notion that the real underlying principle
> is
> > > actually psychokinesis, most likely of the operator but possibly of
> some
> > > external agent as well. This would not require any external 'power' in
> the
> > > sense we normally think of it, and would explain why such voices are
> > > recorded in powered and non-powered devices all using various recording
> > > media. It would also explain the presence of audio and video since PK
> > > appears to be an ability to affect the environment with the mind, which
> > > could extend to manipulating or creating video and audio signals.
> > >
> > > In this context, conducting (or perhaps more correctly replicating)
> tests
> > > in Faraday cages makes sense; in that one could then rule out anything
> > > electromagnetic as a potential source. It may or may not be the case
> that
> > > the sweep signal is critical to voice production. This is actually a
> notion
> > > that needs further clarification - the presence of noise seems
> beneficial,
> > > but is it required? Finding voices inside a Faraday cage in a
> replicated
> > > test would actually be a very helpful outcome to advancing the
> research.
> > >
> > >
> > >
> >
